captions.text: [MOTORCYCLE ENGINE]

JAMIE ROBINSON: This week's
episode I've got Matt Farah
from "Tuned" on the back.
Going to take him for a ride.

He thinks motorcycles are
dangerous, stupid, and, what's
the other thing?
MATT FARAH: Terrifying.
This is such a bad idea.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Welcome to
"RideApart." [MUSIC]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINE]
[MUSIC]

JAMIE ROBINSON: How
was that, man?
MATT FARAH: OK.

That's like being driven around
with like Michael
Schumacher.
Right?

It sounds like a really good
idea, except, going, OK.

He's going to be in
a Formula One car.

But there's going to be
another Formula One
car on top of it.

And oh, the brakes won't
work as well.
And it won't turn as well.
Dude.
Bloody hell, man.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Did you
like it, though?
Did you have a bit of fun?
MATT FARAH: It's terrifying.

You're really good,
by the way.
You are very good.
This is fun.
I'm never doing this again.
Ever.

I will never get on the back of
a motorcycle with another
person, ever.

If you weren't who you are,
I would not be doing this.
Not a chance.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Well,
I am who I am, so
you're coming with me.
MATT FARAH: All right.

One more time for
good measure.

This backpack thing
works, too.

That way I don't have to be
quite as touchy feely with
your groin area.
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINE]
[MUSIC]
JAMIE ROBINSON: You're OK.
And I'm petrified.
[MUSIC]

MATT FARAH: It's a very
interesting experience, being

on the back of a
bike with you.
JAMIE ROBINSON: You reckon?
MATT FARAH: Yeah.

I mean, because first of all,
when you hit the brakes, I'm

like pushing you into
the gas tank.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Man, I have had
a few ball injuries there.

MATT FARAH: Are your nuts
crunched right now?

JAMIE ROBINSON: There's
definitely a left testicle
that's definitely squashed.

MATT FARAH: I'm pretty sure
they can all see my ass.
And you go really fast.

For having someone my size
on the bike, you
going pretty fast.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I'm just--
honestly, I'm not going crazy,

but I'm having some
fun with you.

MATT FARAH: I think the biggest
difference between how

you ride and how I ride is,
you trust the brakes a lot
more than I do.
I don't normally--
on a car, sure.
But on a bike?

I don't get that hard
on the brakes.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, you've got
to get to know your bike.

It's difficult to do that
kind of in a city
environment and stuff.

So that's why I go
into the track.
It's a good idea.

You get to know your
machine, you know?

And I've ridden so many
of these superbikes.

I know straight away, without a
doubt, brakes are damn good.
Right out of the box.

MATT FARAH: Because we've ruined
the power to weight
ratio of this bike.

JAMIE ROBINSON: There's still
a lot of powers to be had.
MATT FARAH: I'm sure.

You're not even going anywhere
near red line.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Oh, man,
I haven't got out
of second gear yet.
MATT FARAH: Of course not.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I've just
been playing in
first and second gear.

MATT FARAH: But you should tell
people at home, advice

for being a passenger
on a bike, probably.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Well the most
important thing, really, is

like I said to you right
at the start.

Is just go with the flow
of the motorcyclist.
Don't move around on the back.

Because when you move
around, I feel it.

And then everything on the
motorcycle is so sensitive,

that, to make corners you make
transitional kind of weight

distribution changes, these
kind of things.

So when you move it changes
that weight around.

I wanted to go right
at one point.

And you moved left, and
I actually went left.
And I was like--
MATT FARAH: That's not good.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Alert,
you know?

But that can be kind of quite
unnerving at times.

Because, to be quite honest,
when you're going around a

corner it's not normal
to want to lean.

But if you lean with the bike
and don't fight it, then you
just become one.

There were some of those tight
turns then that I could take.
I didn't even feel you.

And that's what I
want, you know?

That's what you want
from a passenger.

You don't really know
they're there.

And that really helps
the rider, then.

He can just concentrate
on the job in hand.

MATT FARAH: Well, after
like one run, I sort
of figured it out.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, oh man,
you were dodgy from the start.

MATT FARAH: I think it probably
helps to have someone

that at least is familiar with
riding a bike, though.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, I mean
I've put all kinds of people
on the back.

And some people have had no
experience at all, but the

most important thing, like I
said, is just go with me.
Where I go, you go.
Don't fight it.
Just go along with the ride.

MATT FARAH: But I would say as a
passenger, the scariest part
is the braking.

That's probably, that and that
you like to get my head really
close to objects.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Well you see--

MATT FARAH: I took a cactus
to the face up there.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, but like,
the TT had all of these

kind of like trees,
and all what.

MATT FARAH: You have a
full face helmet on.
Look at me.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Hey, dude,
this comes down.
You can use it.
MATT FARAH: You could--
you said, oh, leave it open.
We want to see your eyes.

JAMIE ROBINSON: If you get
scared, at least you're
going to see it.

MATT FARAH: No one's ever going
to see my eyes again if
I take a cactus to the face.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Well that's the
fun about riding, though.

You can really just pick and
choose where you are on the
road, and feel a part of it.

MATT FARAH: So we're going to
go down-- are we going down
Tuna Canyon?

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah,
man, look at this.
Los Angeles.

We're in heaven right here,
just surrounded
by fantastic roads.

MATT FARAH: Right, and Tuna
Canyon's one of my favorites.
It's narrow.

It's one way, and there's
exposure on every corner.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Oh my god.

If you do go the wrong way over
that guardrail, it's a
long way down.

So at that point, if that does
happen, I'd like you
to let go of me.
Because I know I said--
MATT FARAH: All right.
Fair enough.

JAMIE ROBINSON: All
right, man.
Let's keep going.
[MUSIC]
[MOTORCYCLE ENGINE]
[MUSIC]

JAMIE ROBINSON: The end of the
day of riding on the back of a
CBR1000, on the back of me.
How's that been?

MATT FARAH: Literally, once
in a lifetime experience.

Because I'm never going
to do that ever again.

That was the one and only
time you'll ever
convince me do that.
It was fun though.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, you have
a smile on your face.
MATT FARAH: No, no.
It was fun.
That was fun.

JAMIE ROBINSON: That
was something.

MATT FARAH: It was so
sketchy, though.

JAMIE ROBINSON: So how was
that last half mile?

MATT FARAH: When it gets all
bumpy, and I was like, OK.
You calm down, no.
That's sketchy.

You know what you're
doing, though.
That's for sure.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Ah,
most of the time.
MATT FARAH: Most of the time.

JAMIE ROBINSON: There was a
point when I was braking

downhill hard, and I felt you
on top of me, entirely.

MATT FARAH: Yeah, I was
completely off the seat, like

on my toes-- oh, I just came
right off my seat there--

oh, it was sketchy,
but interesting.

JAMIE ROBINSON: We still had the
corner to go around, and

then when I accelerated
I felt you plop
back down on the seat.

MATT FARAH: All three times
you said, oh that wasn't

supposed to happen, I got
a little nervous.
It was a good time.
I'm glad I came out.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, yeah.
Good, good.
So anyway, you've had bikes.
You're fairly experienced.
You're more of a car guy.

So what does a motorcycle
resemble to you?
MATT FARAH: In terms of a car?

JAMIE ROBINSON: No, just
as a mode of transport.

MATT FARAH: Oh, I mean, I love
getting around LA on a bike,

lane splitting, getting
through traffic.
That stuff is great.

And I really enjoy riding the
canyons at my own speed.

You know, when it goes beyond
the speed that I would

personally ride, it starts
to get scary.

But I know you know
what you're doing.

And I know you don't,
you know--

JAMIE ROBINSON: We scraped
the fair in today.

MATT FARAH: That's probably
my fault.

I don't think that bike is meant
for my weight class on
the back of it.
JAMIE ROBINSON: I mean once--

well, you got better
as the day went on,
anyway, being a passenger.

MATT FARAH: Because the first
run was really scary.

And then I was like, OK, this
is what's going to happen.

And I've got to do this,
and then stay calm.

And then the very last
run was scary too.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Did
it surprise you?

The power of the bike and its
agility to go through corners?

MATT FARAH: The power didn't
surprise me, because I know
these bikes are really fast.

The brakes surprised
me, actually.
I didn't think that--

I mean, I'm sure I knew you
could stop that hard.

But I thought that with my
weight on the back, that the

brakes would be significantly
worse than they were.

And I don't know what percentage
of full threshold
you were breaking at.

Whether it was 60 or
70 or 90 or 100.

But I mean, if I'm off
the bike on you?
Those are good brakes.

JAMIE ROBINSON: You
were literally my
backpack at one point.
MATT FARAH: So sketchy.

Now you have to come
drive my car.
Next time.
JAMIE ROBINSON: I'd love to.
I'd love to.

I'm not much of a
car guy, though.

I've been brought
up about bikes.

My missus has got like a
1-point-something rubbish
Honda Civic.
I have an old '75 van.
I'm not much of a car guy.

MATT FARAH: My car has
500 horsepower.
You'll have a good time.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I'm smiling
already, thinking about that.
That was a fun time.
MATT FARAH: It was.
Thanks a lot, man.
Appreciate it.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Anyway,
thank you, dude.

MATT FARAH: I'm glad--
look, no scratches.
I'm good.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Look,
I told you it was
going to be a fun time.

And that's what you
had, right?
MATT FARAH: Yes.
I had a fun time.
Never again.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Excellent.
He's the man.
He's the man.

MATT FARAH: I'm going
to go home.
JAMIE ROBINSON: On this?
Come on, come on.
Jump on.
Come on.
MATT FARAH: Never.
No.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Come on,
I'll take you home.
I'll take you home, dude.
[MUSIC]
MATT FARAH: [INAUDIBLE].

I think that's the farthest
I've ever been
leaned down on a bike.

JAMIE ROBINSON: We're just
getting started.
MATT FARAH: Oh god.
[MUSIC]

JAMIE ROBINSON: He thinks
motorcycles are no fun at all,
scary, and dangerous.
Let's go and show him.

I have always said I would not be a pillion ever, but if I get to ride with

comments.author: Speed Triple & R1200GS

comments.text:
Well, if this is supposed to be educational video about how to be a 
passenger on a bike then it failed miserably. Holding onto his backpack? 
Seriously? That's pointless. The passenger should ALWAYS support his own 
weight with their hands on the tank, otherwise rider has to support the 
weight of 2 persons when breaking and that is never safe or pleasant for 
the rider. Don't give wrong tips to people just because you think 
passenger's hands on the tank look gay or whatever.
comments.author: MackP

comments.text:
I'm ridiculously scared every time I have a passenger (mainly scared of 
dropping the bike and injuring the passenger), but BEING the passenger? 
FUCK THAT!

comments.text: the excuses are many
comments.author: Dan Frederiksen

comments.text:
Life's about risks, and choosing which risks to take. Some people believe 
that the risk of riding and being injured far outweighs that of driving in 
a car with all sorts of safety doodads. I am one of them. I am not wrong in 
my choice as it's completely subjective. You aren't me, you don't share the 
same tastes, and you will never understand how a motorcyclist could be so 
"stupid" to get back on 2 wheels after a drop/fall/crash. Guess what? 
That's fine! Stay safe, and have a great, long life.
comments.author: Quade235

comments.text:
If you want to avoid the passenger from slamming into your back when 
braking, get them to hug you for when you accelerate, then as you brake 
they can place their hands on the tank and brace that way ;)

comments.text: No pain, no gain. I don't want to sit in a padded box all my life.

comments.author: Dan Frederiksen

comments.text:
What kind of a fucking assumption is that? Nobody dies the moment they lay 
their fingers on a motorbike. If you're law abiding, have your wits about 
you and aren't just generaly idiotic, it can become a great hobby and means 
of transport. You ever been to Asia? You don't get ANYWHERE in a car. It's 
either ride a bus, or ride a bike. What do most normal people choose? The 
bike of course.

comments.text:

will tell you motorcycles are just as dangerous as cars.
